title: while Loops: The Power of Repetition
concept:
Imagine you're washing dishes. You follow this simple process:

  1. Check: Are there still dirty dishes?
  2. If YES: Wash one dish, then go back to step 1
  3. If NO: You're done!

This is a loop - repeating an action while a condition remains true. In code:

while there_are_dirty_dishes:
    wash_one_dish()
    # Loop back and check again

The while loop is Python's way of saying: "Keep doing this action over and over, as long as this condition is True."

Why Loops Matter:

Without loops, if you wanted to print "Hello" 100 times, you'd need to write:

print("Hello")
print("Hello")
print("Hello")
# ... 97 more times!

With a loop:

count = 0
while count < 100:
    print("Hello")
    count = count + 1  # This is critical!
# Done in 4 lines instead of 100!

Real-World Examples:

  • ATM machine:
    WHILE user hasn't entered correct PIN:
        Ask for PIN again
  • Game loop:
    WHILE player is alive:
        Accept player input
        Update game state
        Draw screen
  • Downloading files:
    WHILE download not complete:
        Download next chunk
        Update progress bar
  • Menu system:
    WHILE user hasn't chosen 'quit':
        Show menu
        Get user choice
        Execute action

Loops are the foundation of automation - they let computers do what they do best: repeat tasks tirelessly!

code_example.code:
# while Loops: Repeating Code Based on a Condition

# Example 1: Basic Counting Loop
print("=== Counting to 5 ===")
count = 1  # Start value

while count <= 5:  # Condition: keep going while True
    print(f"Count: {count}")
    count = count + 1  # CRITICAL: Update the variable!

print("Done counting!")
print()

# Example 2: Countdown
print("=== Countdown ===")
countdown = 5

while countdown > 0:
    print(countdown)
    countdown = countdown - 1  # Decrease each time

print("Blastoff! üöÄ")
print()

# Example 3: User Input Loop (Sentinel Pattern)
print("=== Password Checker ===")
password = ""
correct_password = "python123"

while password != correct_password:
    password = input("Enter password: ")
    
    if password != correct_password:
        print("‚ùå Incorrect! Try again.")

print("‚úì Access granted!")
print()

# Example 4: Accumulator Pattern (Sum)
print("=== Sum Calculator ===")
total = 0
number = 1

while number <= 5:
    print(f"Adding {number} to total ({total})")
    total = total + number  # Accumulate sum
    number = number + 1

print(f"Final total: {total}")  # 1+2+3+4+5 = 15
print()

# Example 5: Input Validation Loop
print("=== Age Input with Validation ===")
age = -1  # Invalid starting value

while age < 0 or age > 120:  # Keep looping while invalid
    age = int(input("Enter your age (0-120): "))
    
    if age < 0 or age > 120:
        print("Invalid age! Try again.")

print(f"Thank you! Your age: {age}")
print()

# Example 6: Flag-Controlled Loop
print("=== Menu System ===")
running = True

while running:
    print("\n1. Say Hello")
    print("2. Say Goodbye")
    print("3. Quit")
    
    choice = int(input("Enter choice: "))
    
    if choice == 1:
        print("Hello there!")
    elif choice == 2:
        print("Goodbye!")
    elif choice == 3:
        print("Exiting...")
        running = False  # Change flag to stop loop
    else:
        print("Invalid choice!")

print("Program ended.")

syntax_breakdown:
while Loop Anatomy:

while condition:
    # Code to repeat (loop body)
    # Must be indented!
    statement1
    statement2
    # Update variable(s) in condition!

Breaking It Down:

  1. The keyword: while (lowercase)
  2. The condition: Any Boolean expression
    while count < 10:     # Comparison
while is_running:     # Boolean variable
while password != correct:  # Inequality check
  3. The colon (:): Required! Signals start of loop body
  4. Indented body: Code that repeats (4 spaces)
  5. Variable update: MUST change something in the condition!

How Python Reads a while Loop:

  1. Check condition: Is it True?
  2. If True: Execute indented code
  3. Loop back: Return to step 1 (check again)
  4. If False: Skip loop body, continue after loop

Visual Flow:

count = 1             # Initialize

while count <= 3:     # ‚Üê Check: 1 <= 3? YES
    print(count)      #   Execute: prints 1
    count = count + 1 #   Update: count becomes 2
                       # ‚Üê Loop back, check: 2 <= 3? YES
    print(count)      #   Execute: prints 2
    count = count + 1 #   Update: count becomes 3
                       # ‚Üê Loop back, check: 3 <= 3? YES
    print(count)      #   Execute: prints 3
    count = count + 1 #   Update: count becomes 4
                       # ‚Üê Loop back, check: 4 <= 3? NO
                       # Exit loop

print("Done")         # Continue here

The Three Essential Parts of Most Loops:

  1. Initialization: Set starting values BEFORE the loop
    count = 1  # Initialize counter
  2. Condition: Test that determines if loop continues
    while count <= 5:  # Condition
  3. Update: Change variable(s) to eventually make condition False
        count = count + 1  # Update (progress toward exit)

If you forget the update, you get an INFINITE LOOP!

Common Loop Patterns:

1. Counter Loop (Count N times)

count = 1
while count <= 10:     # Repeat 10 times
    print(f"Iteration {count}")
    count = count + 1  # Increment

2. Sentinel Loop (Until Specific Input)

answer = ""
while answer != "quit":  # Keep going until "quit"
    answer = input("Enter command (or 'quit'): ")
    # Process answer

3. Flag Loop (Boolean Control)

keep_going = True
while keep_going:
    # Do stuff
    choice = input("Continue? (y/n): ")
    if choice == "n":
        keep_going = False  # Exit loop

4. Validation Loop (Repeat Until Valid)

age = -1
while age < 0:  # Repeat while invalid
    age = int(input("Enter age: "))
    if age < 0:
        print("Invalid!")

5. Accumulator Loop (Build Up a Result)

total = 0
count = 1
while count <= 5:
    total = total + count  # Accumulate sum
    count = count + 1
# total now equals 1+2+3+4+5 = 15

Infinite Loops (Common Mistake!):

# INFINITE LOOP - DON'T DO THIS!
count = 1
while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    # OOPS! Forgot to update count
    # count is always 1, so 1 <= 5 is always True
    # Loop runs forever!

# FIX:
count = 1
while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    count = count + 1  # Now it will eventually become 6 and exit

Signs you have an infinite loop:

  • Program never stops running
  • Same output repeats endlessly
  • Computer fan gets loud (CPU working hard!)

How to stop: Press Ctrl+C in the terminal

Common Mistakes:

  1. Missing colon:
    # WRONG:
while count < 5  # Missing colon!
    print(count)

# CORRECT:
while count < 5:  # Has colon
    print(count)
  2. Forgetting to update loop variable:
    # INFINITE LOOP:
count = 0
while count < 10:
    print(count)  # Prints 0 forever!
    # Forgot: count = count + 1
  3. Wrong indentation:
    # WRONG:
while count < 5:
print(count)  # Not indented! Won't loop

# CORRECT:
while count < 5:
    print(count)  # Indented, part of loop
  4. Initializing inside the loop:
    # WRONG:
while count < 5:
    count = 0  # Resets to 0 every iteration! Infinite loop!
    print(count)
    count = count + 1

# CORRECT:
count = 0  # Initialize BEFORE loop
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count = count + 1

exercise.instructions:
Build a Number Guessing Game where the computer picks a random number and the user tries to guess it.

Game Rules:

  • Computer picks a random number between 1 and 20
  • User keeps guessing until they get it right
  • After each guess, tell the user if they're too high or too low
  • Count how many guesses it took

Example game:

=== Number Guessing Game ===
I'm thinking of a number between 1 and 20...

Enter your guess: 10
Too low! Try again.

Enter your guess: 15
Too high! Try again.

Enter your guess: 13
Too low! Try again.

Enter your guess: 14
üéâ Correct! You got it in 4 guesses!

Hints:

  • Use import random and random.randint(1, 20) to pick a number
  • Use a while loop that continues until guess equals the secret number
  • Use a counter variable to track attempts

solution.code:
# Number Guessing Game - SOLUTION
# User tries to guess a random number

import random

print("=== Number Guessing Game ===")
print("I'm thinking of a number between 1 and 20...")
print()

# Pick a random number between 1 and 20
secret_number = random.randint(1, 20)

# Initialize variables
guess = 0  # User's guess (start with impossible value)
attempts = 0  # Counter for number of guesses

# Loop until user guesses correctly
while guess != secret_number:
    
    # Get user's guess
    guess = int(input("Enter your guess: "))
    
    # Increment attempt counter
    attempts = attempts + 1
    
    # Give feedback
    if guess < secret_number:
        print("Too low! Try again.")
        print()
    elif guess > secret_number:
        print("Too high! Try again.")
        print()
    else:
        # Correct guess!
        print(f"üéâ Correct! You got it in {attempts} guesses!")
solution.explanation:
How the Solution Works:

1. Setup (Before the Loop)

import random
secret_number = random.randint(1, 20)  # Pick random number
guess = 0         # Initialize with impossible value
attempts = 0      # Start counter at 0

Why guess = 0? We need an initial value that's NOT equal to secret_number, so the while loop starts. Since the range is 1-20, starting with 0 guarantees the loop runs at least once.

2. The Loop Condition

while guess != secret_number:

Translation: "Keep looping as long as the guess is not equal to the secret number."

  • First iteration: guess is 0, secret_number is (for example) 14 ‚Üí 0 != 14 ‚Üí True ‚Üí Loop runs
  • After correct guess: guess is 14, secret_number is 14 ‚Üí 14 != 14 ‚Üí False ‚Üí Loop exits

3. Inside the Loop (What Repeats)

# Get input
guess = int(input("Enter your guess: "))

# Count this attempt
attempts = attempts + 1

# Give feedback
if guess < secret_number:
    print("Too low!")
elif guess > secret_number:
    print("Too high!")
else:
    print(f"Correct! {attempts} guesses")

4. Step-by-Step Example (secret_number = 14):

IterationguessattemptsCondition (guess != 14)Feedback
Start00True-
110 (user input)1True"Too low!"
218 (user input)2True"Too high!"
314 (user input)3False"Correct! 3 guesses"
---Loop exits-

5. Why the Loop Exits Automatically

When the user guesses correctly:

  1. guess = 14 (matches secret_number)
  2. The else block prints success message
  3. Loop body finishes
  4. Python checks condition: 14 != 14 ‚Üí False
  5. Loop exits automatically!

No need for a break statement - the condition naturally becomes False.

Common Mistakes:

  1. Forgetting to increment attempts:
    # WRONG: attempts never increases
while guess != secret_number:
    guess = int(input("Guess: "))
    # Forgot: attempts = attempts + 1
    # Will always report 0 guesses!
  2. Using = instead of !=:
    # WRONG:
while guess = secret_number:  # Assignment! SyntaxError

# CORRECT:
while guess != secret_number:  # Comparison
  3. Not initializing guess:
    # WRONG:
# guess not initialized
while guess != secret_number:  # NameError! guess doesn't exist

# CORRECT:
guess = 0  # Initialize before loop
while guess != secret_number:
  4. Checking equality in wrong place:
    # INEFFICIENT:
while True:  # Infinite loop
    guess = int(input("Guess: "))
    if guess == secret_number:
        break  # Works, but less clean

# BETTER:
while guess != secret_number:  # Condition in the while
    guess = int(input("Guess: "))
    # No break needed!

Enhancement Ideas:

  • Add input validation (reject numbers outside 1-20)
  • Limit maximum attempts ("You lose after 7 guesses")
  • Track best score across multiple games
  • Add difficulty levels (different number ranges)
  • Show how close the guess was ("Very close!" vs "Way off!")

Why This Pattern is Important:

This sentinel loop pattern (loop until correct input) appears everywhere:

  • Password retry systems
  • Menu selections (loop until valid choice)
  • Game loops (loop until player quits)
  • Data validation (loop until valid entry)

Understanding this pattern is fundamental to interactive programming!

key_takeaways:
• while loops repeat code as long as a condition is True
  • Syntax: while condition: then indented body
  • Three parts: Initialize (before loop), Condition (in while), Update (inside loop)
  • Loop execution: Check condition ‚Üí If True, run body ‚Üí Loop back ‚Üí Check again
  • Must update loop variable or you get an infinite loop!
  • Common patterns:
    • Counter: count to N
    • Sentinel: loop until specific input
    • Flag: Boolean variable controls loop
    • Validation: repeat until valid input
    • Accumulator: build up a result
  • Infinite loops happen when you forget to update the variable in the condition
  • Stop infinite loop: Press Ctrl+C

When to Use while Loops:

‚úÖ Use while when:
‚Ä¢ You don't know how many times to repeat ("until user quits")
‚Ä¢ Condition is based on user input or changing state
‚Ä¢ Input validation (retry until valid)
‚Ä¢ Event-driven loops (game loops, menu systems)

‚ùå Don't use while when:
‚Ä¢ You know exactly how many times to repeat (use for loop - next lesson!)
‚Ä¢ Iterating over a sequence (use for loop)

Before Moving On:

Make sure you can:

  • Write a basic while loop with proper syntax
  • Initialize variables before the loop
  • Update loop variables inside the loop
  • Avoid infinite loops by ensuring the condition eventually becomes False
  • Use while loops for input validation and counters

Coming Up Next:

In Lesson 2: for Loops, you'll learn Python's OTHER loop type:

  • Iterating over sequences (strings, lists, ranges)
  • range() function for counting
  • Cleaner syntax when you know the iterations
  • The difference between for and while

while loops = "repeat WHILE condition is True"
for loops = "repeat FOR each item in a sequence"

Together, these two loop types handle every repetition scenario!
